Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Chloroplast Gene Expression in Plant Growth and Development
Award.AbstractNarration: Chloroplasts play a central role in plant metabolism and in supporting the growth and differentiation of plant cells. Although most chloroplast proteins are encoded in the nucleus, produced in the cytosol, and imported into the chloroplast, few are encoded by the chloroplast genome. Typically, interfering with chloroplast gene function causes defects in photosynthesis, but in some species the effects of such disruptions are more severe and result in early lethality. For example, disrupting chloroplast translation in Arabidopsis often causes embryo lethality, but in other species results in seedlings that are albino, but viable. Recent work suggests that a single chloroplast gene (accD), encoding one subunit of a heteromeric acetyl-CoA carboxylase required for fatty acid biosynthesis, may be responsible for the strikingly different consequences - lethality vs. viable albino - of blocking chloroplast translation in different plant species. This project will evaluate this model, explore its implications for plant biology, and provide valuable insights into basic cellular and metabolic processes that underlie plant development. Several different strategies will be pursued: (1) Determine whether embryo lethality in Arabidopsis mutants defective in chloroplast translation can be rescued by a nuclear transgene encoding a chloroplast-localized version of the normally cytosolic, homomeric carboxylase; (2) Compare the consequences of disrupting chloroplast translation in different accessions of Arabidopsis; and (3) Evaluate plant lineages where accD has been lost from the chloroplast genome. This work will help to illustrate how disrupting genes encoding the same metabolic function in different plant species can have divergent developmental impacts. Results will be published in scientific journals and biological materials distributed to Arabidopsis stock centers. A summer lab course based on this research will be developed to incorporate principles of plant genetics, biochemistry, and evolution, offering biology majors an alternative way to meet lab requirements by focusing on enhanced research, analytical, and writing skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most plant cells have three separate genomes, or complements of genetic material, located in the nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts.  These distinct genomes must function in a coordinated manner to support plant growth and development.  The purpose of this project was to understand why plant species differ in their ability to tolerate a loss of function of the chloroplast genome, or more specifically, chloroplast translation (protein synthesis inside the chloroplast itself).  Most grasses such as maize and rice are somewhat more tolerant of a loss of chloroplast translation than other plant species such as the model dicotyledonous plant Arabidopsis.  We wanted to understand what factors determined these differences.  We became interested in this question when we realized that embryo-defective mutants of Arabidopsis blocked in chloroplast translation exhibit subtle differences in their stage of developmental arrest, and that these differences were dependent on the genetic background in which those mutations arose.  This encouraged us to draw upon the extensive genomic resources available in Arabidopsis to identify genes that vary among Arabidopsis accessions and function to determine plant response to a loss of chloroplast translation. 

Two major experimental approaches were pursued.  In the first, we compared the growth responses of Arabidopsis seedlings germinated on spectinomycin, an antibiotic that specifically inhibits chloroplast translation.  Several hundred natural accessions from various geographical locations, most with sequenced genomes, were analyzed over the course of the project.  Consistent with expectations, considerable variation in seedling responses was observed among these accessions.  But this feature alone was difficult to exploit from an experimental perspective because even the most tolerant seedlings were albino and failed to produce viable seeds in culture. 

The breakthrough came when we realized that embryo-defective mutants unable to carry out chloroplast translation in a natural accession that was highly sensitive to spectinomycin also exhibited an earlier stage of embryo lethality than mutants with a similar genetic defect in a more tolerant accession.  This meant that we could use the early stage of embryo arrest in a mutant defective in chloroplast translation in a sensitive accession ("Nossen") to search for genetic modifiers from a tolerant accession (e.g. Tsu-0) that improved the embryo response.  The second experimental approach therefore involved analyzing the embryo phenotypes of large numbers of progeny from crosses between these two groups of plants.

Remarkably, a number of significant outcomes were realized from this somewhat arcane experimental system.  First, we discovered that a major genetic factor determining tolerance of a loss of chloroplast translation involves fatty acid biosynthesis.  In most plant species, the chloroplast genome encodes one subunit of a key enzyme (heteromeric acetyl-CoA carboxylase) that catalyzes a critical step in fatty acid biosynthesis.  This enzyme is not produced when chloroplast translation is blocked.  For evolutionary reasons that remain unclear, most grasses lack this chloroplast gene, and rely instead on a duplicated nuclear version whose protein product is targeted back to the chloroplast.  Surprisingly, Arabidopsis contains a similar gene duplication, with one nuclear copy (ACC2) encoding a chloroplast-targeted protein.

Our genetic analysis revealed that Arabidopsis accessions differ in the functionality of this duplicated gene.  The most sensitive accessions have a non-functional version of ACC2 and thus are most deficient in fatty acid biosynthesis when chloroplast translation is blocked (Figure 1).  The most tolerant accessions, by contrast, have a functional version but also contain several additional genetic modifiers.  Future analysis of this experimental system promises to provide additional insights into the relationship between chloroplast translation, plant metabolism, chloroplast protein import, and plant development. 

A second outcome involves the development of an experimental system to study the impact of specific genetic variants on the function of acetyl-CoA carboxylase, which is a critical enzyme in human metabolic diseases such as diabetes.  These variants have been difficult to study in other organisms because they are typically lethal.  One advantage to our system is that mutations in the duplicated ACC2 gene have no obvious impact on plant growth in soil, but they can be readily evaluated on spectinomycin.  The mutational landscape for ACCase established here has expanded our understanding of the relationship between gene structure and function for this key metabolic enzyme, which is found throughout eukaryotes.  Notably, this enzyme is also the target of a class of commercial herbicides that specifically disrupt the novel, chloroplast-localized ACCase protein found in weedy grasses.

A final outcome of this project, which illustrates once again the unexpected benefits of basic research, involves recent improvements in chloroplast transformation efficiencies in Arabidopsis reported by Pal Maliga at Rutgers based on insights provided from this project.  By utilizing accessions with non-functional ACC2 in place of standard laboratory accessions, Dr. Maliga has obtained a dramatic improvement in chloroplast transformation (uptake of foreign DNA by chloroplasts) efficiencies, which should soon make it possible to utilize a single experimental plant (Arabidopsis) for research involving both nuclear and chloroplast transformation.
